text:
Eddie Munson has never been picky about his roommates.

He can’t afford to. Not in New York City, where the cost of rent is too high to get choosy about who you live with. Eddie prides himself on his ability to get along with just about everyone, and his past record of roommates proves it.

There was Gareth, an aspiring drummer who practiced day in and day out, despite Eddie’s insistence that he hold off during the night. Then Fred, the former class president who woke up at the crack of dawn to make breakfast and head out to his corporate job. There was Jason, an asshole of a guy, who barely even spoke to Eddie unless he had to.

Sure, they’ve not been the best of friends, but they were pretty upfront with who they were. Eddie knew everything about them that he needed to know. He never came home surprised.

With Steve Harrington, his new roommate as of last spring, he has no idea what to expect.

The man is a mystery. He has two jobs. One as an amateur photographer at the Daily Bugle, and one that Eddie doesn’t know, one he disappears at odd times of the day to work at. Eddie has ideas, sure, but none of them involve legal activities, so he’s never been eager to ask.

Apart from his mysterious job, he has a mysterious home life. He never lets Eddie in his room, going as far to buy a lock and hide the key. Which is a little offensive, because even Jason didn’t do that, but as said before, Eddie gets along with everyone. So he doesn’t bring up the fact that his landlord is going to give him hell for the lock. He just grins and bears it.

He gets along with Steve, he really does. On the off chance he’s home, Steve will let Eddie pick a movie, and they'll eat takeout until they can’t breathe, arguing over the characters, or the plot, or the fucking cinematography.

Steve hates the news. He turns it off any time it’s on, even if Eddie is very obviously watching it. At first, Eddie thought maybe it had something to do with politics, but he’s pretty sure Steve hates local news too. Also podcasts. So Eddie buys earphones and doesn’t think much more about it.

Steve is fucking strong. Eddie actually doesn’t know what to do with this information, other than to tuck it in the furthest parts of his brain, underneath the neon arrow blinking the word Gay Gay Gay over and over. Steve doesn’t even look strong. He’s lean and limber, and he looks like he would do yoga, or something like running. But Eddie never expected him to have actual working muscles under his dorky grandpa sweaters.

He doesn’t think he would’ve known, except for the fact that their neighbor’s — Mrs. Byers — bookcase fell down, not properly anchored to the wall. She had asked the two men over to help her son lift it, the vintage furniture made of solid oak. To Eddie — and the Byers’ — surprise, Steve waltzed right in and lifted the bookcase by himself. And then he anchored the damn thing to the wall.

Eddie has never had to hide a boner so fast.

And so yeah, his roommate is mysterious and strong and probably works for the mafia or something, but he’s pretty cool otherwise. Maybe the best roommate Eddie has had so far.

-

Steve hates living with people.

One would think he might enjoy it, having spent his entire life living alone with no one but his parents, who never stayed home for longer than a weekend. He used to be excited about the prospect of moving in with someone, of sharing takeout menus and a mailbox.

This, of course, was before he got bitten by a radioactive spider, forcing him to lead a double life.

He can’t afford to live alone, but by God does he want to, because living with a roommate runs the risk of them finding out Steve’s biggest secret. New York’s biggest secret, if he’s being honest. And Steve has been doing this since his junior year of high school. He’s good at it.

Eddie Munson makes it extremely difficult.

Steve has never met anyone so friendly, so insistent on getting to know him. It was almost annoying at first; Eddie always asking him to watch a movie or play a video game together. Steve had wanted to lock himself in his room with all of his computers and gadgets, wanted to yell leave me alone and never look at the guy again.

Somehow, Eddie wormed his way into Steve’s heart. Just through sheer willpower alone, which isn’t easy.

Steve has been on this train for awhile now. He has no idea when the Spidey gig ends, but until it does, he has to be careful with who he lets into his life. How he lets them in.

He keeps Eddie at arm’s length. Gives him the movie nights and the takeout and keeps the web shooters and the hostage takeovers. Gives him the grocery runs and keeps the police scanner buried underneath his bed in a box.

Give and take. That’s all it is.

Steve might have this roommate thing down pat.

-

A loud crash wakes Eddie up.

“Shit. Fuck. Shit,” Steve’s voice pierces the silent room.

Eddie leans up on his elbows. Squints into the dark room. “Steve?”

“Shit,” Steve bumps into something. “Sorry, Eddie. I thought I came into my room.”

Eddie blinks. His head is still heavy with sleep. “Did you come in through the window or is this just a really weird dream?”

“It’s a dream,” Steve says quickly. “Go back to sleep.”

The hallway light leaks into Eddie’s room, and he can just barely make out Steve’s form, slipping out of his room.

It wasn’t a dream.

In the morning, Eddie shuffles out of his room in nothing but his sweatpants, ready for his weekend to start with a bagel. Steve is already at the counter, sprinkling everything bagel seasoning onto his avocado toast. He looks as normal as he does every morning, his brown hair awry, his gold-rimmed glasses slipping down his nose and—

Wait. Is that a bruise?

Eddie gasps before he can stop himself. “You have a black eye.”

“Huh?” Steve looks up. He also has a split lip. Eddie can see now, a small cut split open and scabbed over, slicing down his lower lip and chin. “Oh, this?” He gestures to his face way too casually for Eddie’s liking. “I ran into a pole.”

“No you didn’t,” Eddie narrows his eyes. “I know what it looks like to lose a fight, Steve.”

“I didn’t lose,” Steve says, and then he freezes, having caught himself.

Eddie snaps his fingers and jabs his pointer between Steve’s eyes. “Aha! You were in a fight.”

Steve blinks. It looks painful to do so, but he doesn’t wince. He only shrugs. “Okay. So I got into a fight. Does it matter?”

It’s a valid question. Especially when it comes to casual roommates. Eddie has no business sticking his nose where it doesn’t belong. And yet, he wants to know what happened. He wants to know if Steve is okay.

But they’re only roommates. “I guess not,” he finally says.

Steve smiles. This time he does wince. “I took the liberty of putting your bagel in the toaster.”

And they’re back to normal. “Thanks, man.”

(Steve hates the comedown.

After the fight, after the adrenaline kick, after the perps have been webbed up for incoming police — Steve has been doing their job for a while now, let’s face it — after the excitement and the sarcastic quips and the racing of his heart…

Once it’s all over, Steve is left drained of energy. Left to swing home and use the bodega first aid kit he bought a while back to keep his wounds at bay until his skin regenerates. Thank God for that, because he can’t imagine what he’d do if his skin healed at the normal rate. Probably die.

Yeah, definitely die.

He stumbles out of Eddie’s room, feeling incredibly vulnerable, because he’s only wearing his sweats over his suit, having decided to bundle up extra for tonight’s patrol.

It would’ve been nice to savor the sight of a sleepy Eddie, but Steve had been too preoccupied with making sure Eddie couldn’t see him to really stop and get a good look.

Whatever. He’ll be bisexual later.

He rubs at his face with alcohol wipes, ignoring the sharp sting. He’s not good at this part. The healing. The taking care of himself.

Maybe it stems from the fact that he got his powers as a teenage boy and never actually had time to stop and learn how to take care of himself. Maybe it stems from the fact that his parents were never around to teach him. Maybe it stems from the fact that Steve has been known to be pretty hard on himself, and he doesn’t think he’s good at this — at the gentle humanity of it all.

He shuts off the bathroom light.

In the morning, he pretends he doesn’t see Eddie’s frown as he studies the wounds across his face. He’s good at that — at the pretending.)

-

Here’s the thing: sometimes, Eddie feels like he’s being watched.

It started a few weeks ago; this prickly feeling along the back of his neck, like someone has just brushed their fingers along his spine. It’s eerie, and it happens during the night, usually when he’s walking home from his late shift at the bar.

It’s happening right now. Eddie takes his earphones out of his ears just to be aware of his surroundings. The streets of Brooklyn aren’t exactly safe, but he’s usually not this on edge.

His shift had been shit. He accidentally broke a bottle of expensive ass tequila, and his boss made sure to let him know it would be coming out of his paycheck.

So, when a man rounds the corner of the alley, drawing a knife on Eddie and demanding he hand over his wallet, Eddie finds himself thinking yeah, this might as well happen.

He pulls his wallet out of his pocket and is just about to hand it over, ID and everything, because he’s not gonna fight, when something swings down from the roof, kicking the mugger directly in the jaw.

Critical hit, Eddie thinks to himself, unhelpfully. He stands there and watches New York’s resident hero lecture the dude on the ethics of mugging.

Of course Eddie knows who Spider-Man is. Except in his mind, he’s always thought of the hero as someone like Banksy. Someone who is untouchable, a bit of a mystery to the entire city, yet still just some random dude. He can’t say he ever thought he’d be this close to the guy. Or maybe girl? He’s not sure and honestly it doesn’t matter, because whoever they are, they’re walking up to Eddie. “You okay, man?”

He’s deepening his voice on purpose. Eddie can tell. It’s probably part of the whole secret identity thing. Eddie doesn’t really care. He’s pretty sure he sees a different masked stranger every day on the subway alone, so forgive him if he’s not incredibly wowed by this guy’s presence just because he is a bit campy with the way he goes about it. “Yeah,” he answers. “Thanks for, uh, saving my wallet.”

The spandex is tight. Eddie can see the hero’s body very clearly. His tapered waist and strong thighs. The suit is doing wonders for him, and Eddie momentarily weighs the option of asking Spider-Man if he’s gay. Then, he mentally chides himself for thinking he has a chance with Spider-Man.

This night is really not going the way Eddie expected it to.

“You shouldn’t walk home alone,” Spider-Man says. The eye lenses on his suit narrow, like he’s actually upset with Eddie. “Do you have a friend who could pick you up?”

Eddie has like, two friends in the entire city. Chrissy, who works across town in the mayor’s office, of all places. She and Eddie don’t even cross paths unless they purposefully make plans to. So she’s out of the picture. The only other person he can think of is Steve, and that’s a hard no. For all Eddie knows, Steve could be the one out here mugging. “No,” he answers. “I’m okay, though. I’m a big boy.”

Spider-Man crosses his arms over his chest. “Someone might worry about you.”

Eddie raises his brows. “No one worries about me. I take this route all the time.”

“Take this,” Spider-Man holds out what looks like a little earpiece.

“What is this?”

“A doohickey,” he says, like it’s obvious. “You stick it in your ear and press a button, and it’ll call me. If something like this happens again.”

Eddie stares at the small, hand painted spider design on the earpiece. It’s a bit elaborate for the whole performative vigilante thing this guy has going on, but he appreciates the consistency in theme. “Um. Okay.”

“Okay,” Spider-Man breathes out a sigh, like he is actually concerned about Eddie’s wellbeing.

Maybe he is. “Do I know you?”

“What?” Spider-Man straightens up. Eddie hears a glimpse of his real voice for a moment, and it’s almost familiar, but then it’s back to that phony deep voice again. “Absolutely not,” and his eye lenses are thinning like he’s angry.

“Okay,” Eddie raises his hands in surrender. “Just asking.”

Spider-Man stares at Eddie.

Eddie stares at Spider-Man. “So… Can I go home now?”

“Oh, right,” Spider-Man clears his throat, “Of course!” He steps out of Eddie’s way and lifts his hand in a wave “Have a nice night.”

“You too, Spidey,” Eddie mumbles. He passes the hero, giving him one last scrutinizing look for good measure.

-

Steve doesn’t know when following Eddie home from his late shifts at the bar became an integral part of his night patrol, but here he fucking is, standing in an alleyway, waiting for the cops to come take away the guy he probably could’ve gone a little bit easier on, if he’s being honest with himself.

But it’s Eddie. Was Eddie.

Steve’s roommate is probably home by now, getting ready for bed. Taking a shower, running his fingers through those shaggy curls, getting out the kinks and the tangles of the day.

Steve huffs.

He’s not sure when his acquaintanceship with Eddie became something closer to a crush, but here he is, following the man home like he can’t take care of himself. Sharing actual Spidey equipment with him like he’s in on the secret.

Steve swings away to finish his night patrol, lets the autumn wind soothe the burning heat in his face.

More secrets to keep. Alter-ego, bisexuality, crush on roommate — the list is stupid and long. Steve has always been a bit of a disaster. He can never tackle one thing at a time. He’s gotta be an overachiever, gotta have multiple issues to deal with at once.

He fights a few more perps, helps someone get home after their car stalls, and gets home with only a few easy-to-hide scrapes.

He cleans them up in the darkness of his room. Alone with his thoughts.

-

Steve takes baths often.

This can be annoying because they share a bathroom, their small apartment only having room for one. So, if Eddie needs to use the restroom, he has to wait for Steve to finish up his bath. Which, if he’s completely honest, never takes more than thirty minutes, tops. But after a thirty-two ounce coke from the bodega down the street, it feels like hours.

Another thing that’s a result of Steve’s baths: the bathroom is always stocked full of good-smelling salts and scrubs. He’s actually pretty sure he’s going to buy Steve a Lush gift card for Christmas this year, considering the amount of little bath bombs he hoards beneath the sink.

Eddie is turning a spider shaped one around in his hand, reminiscing his weird ass night last night, when Steve passes by the doorway.

“That’s a special Blueberry scent for Halloween,” he says, unprompted. “Boo-berry.”

Eddie looks up. Steve is leaning on the door jam, arms crossed casually. He’s wearing a brown Sherpa jacket over his usual cuffed jeans. The sleeves are so long they reach past his knuckles, making him look soft and cozy as he explains Lush bath bombs to Eddie like they’re a foreign concept. “You’ve had this thing since last Halloween?”

Steve looks sheepish. A pretty shade of pink blooms across his neck. “I like putting them in my drawers to make everything smell good,” he says, as if that explains everything. “I probably have too many. You can totally use a few up if you want to. I should’ve told you that before.”

Eddie glances back at the spider. He wonders if it turns the bath water black. If that’s appealing to customers like Steve. He puts it back in its place. “I’m not a bath guy.”

“I have shower fizzers, too,” Steve says.

The words come out before Eddie can think to stop them: “You’re fucking adorable.”

Somehow, the red in Steve’s neck creeps all the way up to his cheeks. “Thanks,” he squeaks. He pushes himself off the wall and escapes, leaving Eddie with his thoughts and about thirty bath bombs.

“I don’t know if he’s gay, is the thing,” Eddie is saying as he wipes down the bar. Some asshole spilt his beer earlier and never cleaned it up, leaving a sticky residue that is now Eddie’s job to fix. His manager still hasn’t forgiven him for the tequila incident a few weeks ago, so Eddie’s not eager to make a mistake again, if he can help it.

“Why can’t you just ask?” Chrissy uses a cherry stem to poke at the floating ice cubes in her Shirley Temple.

“I don’t want to make him uncomfortable,” Eddie says while he pours some Guinness for a girl in a Dodgers cap. “What if he thinks I’m coming on to him?”

“Aren’t you?” Chrissy asks.

“He’s my roommate,” Eddie gives her a flat look. He rings up someone’s tab. Gives them a polite smile so they know he’s not ignoring them. “That’s like, rule number one of roommate etiquette.”

Chrissy hums. “I fucked Heather back when we were roommates.”

Eddie rolls his eyes. “Yes, well, I’m not sure I have your luck when it comes to partners.”

Chrissy sips her drink through a pink straw. “You do have luck when it comes to masked heroes, though.”

“I was wondering how long it would take you to bring that up.”

“I can’t believe Spider-Man gave you one of his little spy gadgets,” Chrissy says, eyes wide. “That’s like, second base I think.”

“I think you don’t know what second base is.”

“Whatever,” Chrissy waves his worries away. “You’re gonna call him, right?”

Eddie glances down the length of the bar to make sure no one needs him. “Pretty sure it’s for emergencies only.”

“You should just call him once,” Chrissy prompts. “Just to see what he does.”

“Yeah, that’ll happen.”

-

It does happen, three days later, when Eddie is so high he can’t actually think straight.

He’s sitting on the fire escape in a folding chair, one of the spare quilts he keeps in the linen closet draped over his lap to keep the autumn chill at a minimum. He’s on his second joint, having built a pretty decent tolerance during his time here. It helps that he has an actual job now and can afford the good stuff.

He blows smoke rings into the polluted sky, smiling lazily as they dissipate.

He reaches in his pocket for his zippo, wanting something to fidget with, but his fingers catch on the doohickey instead. It’s just an earpiece. He’s not sure why Spider-Man calls it something different. Before he can talk himself out of it, he’s clicking the button and sticking the little device in his ear.

“Spidey Speaking.”

“It’s the guy you saved from that mugging a few weeks ago..?” Eddie starts. Now that he’s hearing the man’s voice on the other end, he feels a little stupid.

“Are you okay? Do you need help?”

“Yeah, I need help,” Eddie lies. He’s not sure why he lies, but he likes the idea of seeing the masked hero again. Even if he comes to take Eddie’s doohickey privileges away.

In reality, this guy is definitely just some rando who gets a power trip out of anonymity. Probably.

“I’m tracking you,” Spider-Man says. All business. “I’ll be there as soon as I can.”

Okay. Spider-Man is coming to his house. Eddie waits. He pulls out his zippo and flips it open, then shut, then open, then shut. Open, shut, open, shut, open, shut–

“I thought you said you needed help.” Spider-Man perches on the rusty railing, resembling a red and blue gargoyle. He cocks his masked head to the side. “You interrupted my night patrol, man,” there’s a mechanism to his voice now. Something deep and warped.

“I wanted to see if it worked,” Eddie says. He’s starting to feel a little giggly. He’s way too high. Sober Eddie would never take a risk like this. “If you’d come.”

“I told you I would,” Spider-Man says. Like he’s confused as to why Eddie wouldn’t trust him. Which is silly, because Eddie doesn’t know him.

“You’re funny,” Eddie says. He takes one last hit before snubbing out what’s left of the joint in Steve's makeshift ashtray, figuring he’ll collect the roach later. Both of their bedrooms lead out to the same fire escape, except Steve actually opposes littering, and uses a sawed off McDonald’s cup as a place to store old cigarettes and joints. “I’m not going to trust you just because you’re a hero.”

“But I’m your–” Spider-Man cuts himself off and stands upright without the use of his arms. Just shoots right up, completely balanced. The action makes Eddie a bit dizzy. “Anyway, what’re you doing on this fine September night?”

“Jus’ smoking,” Eddie shrugs. “If my roommate was here, we’d be watching some trash tv. Real Housewives or some shit. But he’s off doing God-knows-what with God-knows-who.”

Spider-Man snorts. “Are you pouting?”

“I’m a water sign!” Eddie says defensively. “I like quality time with my friends!” And he likes Steve more than all his other friends, even if he’s not ready to admit it.

“He’s your friend?” Spider-Man sounds… surprised? Touched?

Eddie is confused. “Why wouldn’t he be? Are you not friends with your roommates? I mean, assuming you have roommates?”

“I’m a young adult in New York, of course I have a roommate,” Spidey drawls. He walks the railing like a tightrope. Back and forth and back and forth. Arms stretched out, even though Eddie is pretty sure he doesn’t need the extra balance. “Just… I dunno… you can’t always trust roommates, can you? You don’t exactly know them from Adam.”

“I don’t think it’s that deep,” Eddie says. He flips his zippo. “Then again, I suppose you have to watch everyone you’re around, if you’re planning on keeping this whole anonymous hero thing going.”

The band around Spider-Man’s wrist suddenly beeps, flashing a bright red blinking light. Spidey hits it, and a voice comes through, lispy and high, “We got a cartel shootout two blocks away. I don’t know why you’re at your–”

Spider-Man slaps the band again, and the voice cuts out. “Well,” he chuckles. It sounds fake. “Duty calls!”

He gives Eddie what looks like the rocker symbol, and then a web is shooting out of his wrist, landing on the roof of their building. Spider-Man wraps his hand around the string and uses the tension to propel himself upwards.

Eddie waits ten minutes, just in case he decides to come back, and then goes inside.

-

Chrissy comes over one Friday with a box of pizza and a Pitch Perfect DVD. Which can only mean one thing.

“You and Heather are on another break,” Eddie deadpans. He pulls the door open wider, so Chrissy can come in. “Steve is here,” he tells her as she passes. There’s some unspoken warning in the words, like please don’t say anything embarrassing about me.

“Hey, Steve!” Chrissy says, donning her sweetest voice. “I hope you like meat lovers and Rebel Wilson!”

Steve peaks over the top of his laptop. He’s been editing pictures for the last hour. Eddie’s pretty sure he has a deadline to meet, so he’s been trying to stay out of his way. “Oh, thanks, Chrissy. Meat lovers is fine.”

“What’re you doing?” Chrissy leaves the pizza box on the counter and peers over Steve’s shoulder. “Ooh… are these your pictures for The Bugle?”

Eddie wonders how Chrissy does it; just jumps into a conversation like Steve isn’t the cutest man alive. He supposes it’s the whole lesbian thing, but still, aestheticism and all that. He opens the box and takes out a slice of pizza.

“Yeah,” Steve answers. His neck is that pretty shade of pink again, almost matching the neon shade of his argyle sweater vest. He shoves his glasses further up his nose, and Eddie focuses on his copper eyes as they scan across his laptop screen. “I’m still editing–”

“They look great,” Chrissy says. She smirks, glancing at Eddie. “Does Eddie know you take pictures of Spider-Man for a living?”

“What?” Eddie asks, his mouth full. He drops his pizza back into the box and rounds the counter, practically pressing into Steve as he peers over his shoulder and squints at the screen.

The pictures are amazing. Eddie doesn’t know much about photography, but he can tell Steve is fucking good at it. Every picture of Spider-Man looks like something out of a movie, all the right angles and perfect lighting. One hardly notices the alley of overflowing dumpsters in the background, or the gray smoke lingering behind the hero. “These are fucking metal.”

“T-Thanks,” Steve mumbles.

“Eddie loves Spider-Man,” Chrissy says.

“He does?” Steve tenses. Eddie can feel it in the shoulder that’s touching his chest. “That’s cool. He’s cool. Spider-Man, not Eddie. I mean, Eddie, you’re cool–”

It’s easy to pay the fare and sit in the same place for five hours when he knows Eddie will be back at the apartment, happy to see him.

Well, happy to see Spider-Man.

The latter fact dims his mood only slightly. Steve is partially certain he’d glue the vizard to his face if it meant receiving Eddie’s affection in return. Which, thinking it over, is probably not a healthy thought to have, but Steve isn’t exactly the poster child for self esteem, so…

He sleeps three out of the five hours, and spends the rest of the time listening to podcasts through his earphones. He also texts both Robin and Lucas to see how their Thanksgivings went.

Lucas stays in the city because he lives in the city, along with his family. He had told Steve enthusiastically that Thanksgiving is one of the only holidays he gets to see his favorite uncle.

Robin, since turning eighteen, has vehemently avoided visiting her family, so she stays in the city as well. She usually invites Steve over in the beginning of December for a weekend of drinking and stalking old classmates on Facebook. All the best drama happens around the holidays, and Robin’s friend list is perfectly curated to showcase the most dramatic posts first. It’s something Steve always looks forward to.

He knows he’ll have to take up Christmas patrol to make up for his long holiday. It’s always like this when the holidays pile up: he and Robin trading off the city like they share custody. Now Lucas gets to join in on the fun. Maybe Steve could convince them to do some spidey-caroling. He did that one year, and there’s nothing funnier than singing to a bunch of perplexed New Yorkers on Christmas Eve.

He uses the bus station bathroom to change into his suit, stuffs his civilian clothes in a bush outside of the station, and crawls out of a hallway window. The quick swing back home is enough to make Steve excited. He never has someone to come home to. Now he does.

It’s not quite in the way he would like, but he cherishes it nonetheless.

Eddie’s curtains are drawn, his window closed. For a moment, Steve wonders if Eddie has gone out, or if he’s sleeping. Maybe he doesn’t actually want to see Spider-Man. Maybe Steve is thinking too much into this–

He knocks on the window.

It’s just after noon. The sun is high in the sky but the entire city wears a chill that wasn’t there a week ago. It’s decorated as usual, seemingly overnight, wreathes on streetlights and those bigass ornaments stacked across from Radio City Music Hall. The tree lighting won’t happen until tomorrow, which is a bummer, because Steve would like to see it. But he saw the unlit tree briefly as he zipped by, which satisfies him enough.

Eddie’s window is pushed open. Eddie, in all his sweetness, is there, wearing a Christmas sweater over a pair of plaid pants. “Merry Christmas, Spidey!”

Steve groans. He forgot that Eddie is the type to start decorating as soon as the calendar page turns. “My turkey hasn’t even digested yet,” he tells Eddie. “Give it a minute.”

“No way,” Eddie grabs something from his room and then climbs out onto the escape. The thing he grabbed is a mug of hot chocolate, topped with marshmallows and a candy cane for stirring. “This is the best time of the year!”

“You’re like a walking commercial.”

“Thanks,” Eddie giggles, his cheeks flushed, and Steve wonders if he’s just a little bit day-drunk. “Hey, Spidey, you should change your suit colors to red and green. Just for the month.”

“I will not be doing that,” Steve deadpans. His voice sounds so weird through the mechanism. He barely ever activates it, since hardly anyone in New York knows Steve Harrington enough to recognize his voice, but with Eddie he needs the extra layer of protection.

Eddie slumps into his chair the way he always does, pulls a lighter out of his pocket and a joint from behind his ear. “Didn’t know Spidey was such a Scrooge,” he mumbles around the stick.

“I’m not,” Steve argues helplessly. He reaches out and takes the stick from Eddie’s lips. From his perch on the railing, he has the perfect view of Eddie’s doe eyes, brown and sparkly in the glow of the fairy lights hanging from the apartment above them. “I like the holidays. Less crime.”

Eddie hums. “Guess that makes sense. Why do the holidays make people happier?”

“Subliminal messaging?” Steve guesses with a shrug. He lifts his mask and takes a puff, but instead of turning to shield himself, he leaves the mask rolled up just at the bridge of his nose. The air is cooler outside of the mask, not as moist from his breath. His incessant need to chatter with his enemies can really fog up the lenses. Maybe that will be his next project: better mask ventilation. “All those songs about the best time of the year… plus Christmas bonuses… and I guess visiting family, if you like your family…”

“Do you like your family?” Eddie’s already high. Maybe he finished off a joint inside, which is something he does when Steve’s not home, as if the smell of weed doesn’t seep into every fabric in the entire place, immediately outing him.

“I don’t not like them,” Steve shrugs. “It’s just complicated, I guess. I’m okay to see them on the holidays, but that’s pretty much it. They’re not really interested in anyone who isn’t paired up or having kids, so I’m all but chopped liver.”

“No kids, Spidey?”

“I wish,” Steve says before he can help himself, and the admission shocks Eddie, who blinks owlishly at him. “I mean, wouldn’t it be cool to have a bunch of spiderlings running around?”

“I’m imagining a baby crawling up a wall,” Eddie says, giggling. “Which sounds like parenting hell.”

“It won’t happen anyway,” Steve takes one last pull and then hands the joint back to Eddie.

“Why not?”

Steve shrugs. “I’m not sure it would be safe to go off and have a family. Knowing what they might go through if any of my enemies found out about them… And I wouldn’t want to keep it a secret either but… I don’t know. It’s too complicated.”

Eddie’s cheeks hollow when he sucks in. But they're fuller tonight, like he ate well this past weekend, which comforts Steve in the pit of his chest. He wants to kiss Eddie suddenly, press against him until he can feel his teeth through his skin. Feel his cozy-warm stomach beneath his sweater.

“I get not wanting kids,” Eddie says. “Maybe wait until after you retire and can get one of those witness protection houses or something. But what would be wrong with a partner? I mean, an adult would know what they’re getting into.”

“They really wouldn’t,” Steve says. He’s thinking of nights bound and gagged, starved and dehydrated, forced to sit and pray he’d figure a way out of whatever mess he got himself into — that they wouldn’t find his parents or his friends, and the thought, the fear, of putting Eddie in that kind of situation, some scary, fucked up situation that could be prevented, makes Steve’s chest twinge in pain. He feels dizzy all at once. “Anyone I love is safer not knowing.”

Dear God it’s true even though he wishes it weren’t. He wishes he were more powerful. That he was all-knowing. That he could prevent danger and confess to Eddie, but he’s just not sure that’s the case. Or that that will ever be the case.

“You gotta know that if someone loves you, they’d be willing to go through all the spidey shit, too,” Eddie says. He waves his joint around as if to make a point, “And you gotta know that you’re worth all the spidey shit.”

Steve blinks at him. “I don’t– It’s really dangerous, Eddie–”

“Some of us like danger,” Eddie drawls, a lazy smile on his face as he lulls his head to the side and peers up at Steve. There’s something in his eyes, like hope, or the promise of hope. “Just so you know.”

Eddie spends the two days before Steve gets home fixing up the house and getting it ready for decorating. He vacuums the rugs, the drapes, and the couches. He wipes down the walls and the counter and splurges on some new air fresheners that smell like citrus and spruce. But when he’s in Boston, reading Eddie’s texts but not answering them, posting pictures on his private Instagram of him holding his baby nieces and nephews, Eddie thinks he may be losing his mind.

He tries to call Spider-Man, but the hero doesn’t answer. So Eddie checks social media to see what he’s been up to, and it turns out Spider-Man hasn’t been seen in the city for awhile, except for the day he came to see Eddie.

Which is weird. That knowledge tickles some part of Eddie’s brain, and it feels a bit like there’s a word at the tip of his tongue but he can’t quite figure it out.

It becomes paranoia as the day fades. Eddie flips through the channels until he finds something he can focus on, but nothing is sticking. He starts scrolling through his phone and ends up on Steve’s cousin’s Instagram story, watching their day play out and hoping Steve will show up in the background.

The word pathetic crosses his mind a few times.

He downloads tinder, deletes it, downloads it again, but then he sees a profile of some guy taking a selfie with Spider-Man, so he deletes it for good and stuffs his phone down between the couch cushions in the hopes of tricking his brain into doing something else. Out of sight, out of mind.

Eddie doesn’t know where he stands with Spider-Man. He watches the ceiling fan spin and tries to sort facts from feelings the way his childhood therapist taught him to.

He kissed Spider-Man. Fact.

Spider-Man kissed him back. Fact.

Eddie likes Spider-Man. Fact, but also feeling.

Spider-Man seems to like Eddie back. Fact.

Eddie likes Steve. Fact that will never leave his head. Feeling that will never leave his heart.

Steve doesn’t like Eddie back. Feeling.

Steve will never like Eddie back. The worst feeling in the entire world.

Eddie works a double the morning Steve gets back in from Boston. Taking more shifts is good for him, he thinks. It forces him to think about something that isn’t Steve. Or Spider-Man.

He gets into his busywork. Mixing drinks and ignoring drunken small talk because he doesn’t get paid to talk to people, thank God. He does listen to the bar gossip, though, and when a large group of sorority girls file in, he nearly sighs in relief, because they always have the best stories.

With their company, the shift passes quickly, and Eddie is in good spirits on his walk home.

Miraculously, he forgets that Steve is due home this morning. He’s tired on his feet, ready to crawl under his covers and sleep the entire day away, but when he opens the door, Steve is in the kitchen, mixing something in a bowl.

The entire apartment smells like chocolate.

“What’s going on?” Eddie leans against the counter and closes his eyes. Inhales. “Smells like heaven in here.”

When he opens his eyes, Steve is staring at him, cheeks pink. “Um.” He blinks, eyes tracing over Eddie’s face for so long that Eddie reaches up, wipes at his mouth in case there’s any food left from the snack break he took three hours ago. “Brownies.” He holds up the bowl.

Eddie rests his chin on his palm, watches Steve putter around. He feels warm all over, because Steve is in comfy clothes — sweatpants and a hoodie. His glasses make him look adorable, and his hair must’ve been recently washed, because his waves are curled more than usual. And, now that he can identify the brownie smell, Eddie can also smell the foggy scent of Steve’s shampoo, and maybe a bath bomb or two. “Did you take a bath?”

“Yeah,” Steve mumbles. “Used a peppermint vanilla bath bomb. It was shaped like a candy cane.”

“Very festive,” Eddie comments. He bites down any other quip he wants to say, like you’re so cute, please tell me more about your goofy bath bombs, and I love you.

I love you so much and I want this forever. You in the kitchen with your fake glasses and your overpriced soaps and your store-bought brownie mix.

“Why are you looking at me like that?” Steve pours the batter into a greased pan and shoves it in the preheated oven.

“Like what?” Eddie yawns, realizes he won’t be awake for much longer. He probably won’t even be able to wait until the brownies are done.

“Like you’re–” Steve bites his lip and looks away. He walks over to the fridge, opens the door, pulls out a bottle of beer. He shakes his head. “Nevermind. ‘s Stupid.”

“Nothing you say is stupid,” Eddie mumbles, his eyes closing. God, he’s so tired. And he smells boozy. He should shower but he doesn’t think he can stay awake long enough to.

“How long was your shift?” Steve’s voice is kind. Eddie doesn’t have to open his eyes to know that Steve is probably looking at him with big, worried eyes.

“I worked a double. Been there since ten last night.”

“Go to sleep, Eddie.”

“Don’t wanna,” Eddie says, even though he’s halfway into dreamland already. “Wanna stay up and talk to you. And we’re supposed to decorate now that you’re back.”

Steve hums. “I’ll be here when you wake up. We can do it then.”

“Promise?”

“Promise,” and Steve’s voice sounds closer. “Need me to carry you to bed?”

He’s teasing, but the question leaves a flutter of butterflies to battle behind Eddie’s ribcage. “Yes,” he says, pouting and playing along. “My bones are like mush.”

“Hold on, ‘kay?” Steve mumbles into Eddie’s ear.

“Why? What are you– Steve!”

Steve scoops Eddie up like he weighs nothing, one arm under his back and one beneath the bend of his knees. He isn’t even breathing differently, Eddie thinks. He buries his face in Steve’s neck to keep the man from seeing just how much his strength affects Eddie. Honestly, where does he get the strength from?

Steve drops Eddie onto his bed with measured ease. His core strength must be insane. He pulls the blankets up over Eddie’s body and tucks him in. “Here. Get some sleep.”

“I’m in my work clothes,” Eddie bemoans.

“So take them off,” Steve says casually like Eddie stripping down to his underwear in front of him wouldn't send him into an immediate spiral.

“Go away,” he says weakly. “Go bake your stupid brownies.”

Steve snorts. Eddie feels Steve’s fingernails scratch at his head. I love you, he’s thinking again. I’ll never love anyone more.

Steve’s knuckles brush over Eddie’s cheek, feather-light. It’s the last thing Eddie feels before he gives himself away to sleep.

Steve takes less hours at the lab and sends more shots of Spider-Man to Jameson — through email this time, so he doesn’t have to step foot in that godawful building again. Time is getting easier to manage. He speaks to his boss about more flexible hours, and they work out something that makes everything feel a bit easier.

He spends his spare time in his room, working on a new suit design; this one has heated pads in the hands, feet, and torso that can be activated through the control panel on his wrist. It also has better ventilation in the suit, and it will have Bluetooth built into the mask, so that Steve can activate it through voice.

His new boss, Otto Octavius, seems to like him. He gives him access to one of the private labs, and Steve has enough space to prototype his suits and web shooters. He’s been working on an electric web prototype after his run in with Electro two years ago. He’s never quite perfected it, though, and there’s a lot of things that could go wrong if he doesn’t get the mechanics down.

He sneaks Lucas, Dustin, and Robin in and out of the lab when he can. They work in tandem; Max visits every now and again with takeout. One conversation with her, and Steve can see why Lucas likes her so much. He wonders how the others would react to Eddie if he ever gets the strength to tell him. Would they welcome him as easily as they’ve welcomed Max?

Whatever. That’s why he has an actual job now.

December nights are spent at home, watching reruns of Christmas specials while Eddie stumbles around, getting ready for work. He’s taken on extra shifts, apparently staff morale is lower around the holidays, and, as he told Steve, Eddie has no reason not to go to work.

Steve wonders what he would have to do to be the reason Eddie stayed home a night or two. If Eddie would ever just say fuck it and sit beside him, sharing the warmth of Steve’s blanket while they watch what feels like Friends’ twentieth Christmas-centered episode. Maybe it’s as simple as Steve verbalizing his wants; asking for Eddie to stay with him.

But work is work, and Steve doesn’t want to get in the way of that, so he watches numbly while Eddie slips out into the cold, bundled up from head to toe.

He tries to focus on the television but the images bleed into each other. Steve finds himself pacing the hallway, ultimately sneaking into Eddie’s room.

It’s just going to be a quick nap, he thinks. A quick nap, and then he’ll move back into his cold, industrial room, and Eddie will never know that Steve craves the ghost of him that lingers on his sheets.

He falls asleep right away, and stays asleep through the night.

(When Eddie comes home from his five-hour shift, he’s ready to climb into bed and snooze the rest of the night away.

He shuffles around the apartment quietly, sure Steve is fast asleep in his own room. He takes a shower as quickly as he can, pulling on a pair of boxers he left folded on the sink for this precise moment — thank you, past Eddie.

The last thing he expects to see when he enters his room is Steve, curled into his sheets, hugging his pillow to his chest. Eddie’s heart melts at the sight, and he does his best to climb into bed beside Steve without waking him.

He sleeps without a pillow. It’s an easy sacrifice to make.)

Sometimes Steve forgets Eddie doesn’t know that he’s bisexual.

It’s an easy thing to keep from people — Steve has always been too busy to pursue anyone, so people hardly ever question his relationship status. It might be weird for a guy who doesn’t date to come out as bisexual; it might be anticlimactic. Steve might tell everyone and they might laugh at him, or tell them they knew already, or worse yet, tell him it doesn’t matter because he’ll never get anyone anyways.

The last one is a bit hyperbolic, but Steve has radioactive spider powers, so forgive him if his mind jumps to the worst case scenario first.

Eddie doesn’t mention Steve’s love life, or lack thereof, often, or even at all. But he is hesitant at times to touch Steve.

Steve wouldn’t notice it if Eddie was just a normal roommate. But Eddie is, unfortunately, the most endearing person Steve has ever met, and he’s wormed his way into Steve’s heart with little to no warning. Which means Steve just has to stand here and take it — a heart full of Eddie — and act like it’s not the only thing he thinks about nowadays.

He knows Eddie is gay. It’s not exactly something the man keeps hidden from everyone. Sometimes, he’ll make little quips about Steve’s “straightness”. Normal jokes recycled from Twitter, and they would be funny if Steve were straight. Sometimes, Eddie will reach out for affection, and he’ll draw back just as quickly, as if he’s not sure what’s crossing the line for a “straight guy” like Steve.

But he’s not straight. He wants to tell Eddie as much, nearly every day now, because it feels like something Eddie should know. It feels like maybe, just maybe, Steve would have a chance with Eddie if Eddie knew.

Like maybe Steve’s availability might put him on Eddie’s radar, at the least.

They’re eating pizza on Eddie’s bed, too cold to leave the only room with a proper heater. And sure, they could bring the space heater into the living room or kitchen, but Steve doubts it would be as cozy as it is in here, where the room smells like Eddie; pine and cinnamon and a little bit of smoke.

They’re eating on top of the covers, classic rock covers of Christmas songs crooning between them from Eddie’s phone speaker.

Eddie is telling Steve about the awful holiday drinks he has to mix this month. Steve is thinking about how much he wants to kiss him.

It’s a lot: the want to kiss a friend. Someone so close but so far away. Because Eddie and Spider-Man have kissed. This leads Steve to think Eddie must like Spider-Man: must have some sort of romantic feelings for him. But would those feelings transfer if Eddie knew who Spider-Man was? Or would Eddie feel betrayed? Would he kick Steve out and never speak to him again?

“Stevie? Did I lose you?” Eddie waves his pizza crust in front of Steve’s face.

“I have to tell you something,” Steve says. Fuck it, he’ll just get it out there. His second scariest secret to tell, and he’s already said it to Eddie once, behind a mask, so it’s not like this would be any different, right?

Eddie’s brows furrow. “Okay. What is it?”

Steve watches Eddie place the crust in the pizza box. He watches him close the box and set it on the floor. He watches him grab a few napkins and wipe his hands of any sauce that might reside. He passes a clean napkin to Steve, and Steve wrings it in between his fingers. “I’m bisexual.”

Eddie blinks. “Oh.” He blinks again, looks away. “I wasn’t expecting– Wait, what? Really?”

“Really,” Steve says, rolling his shoulders back. Loosening the tension. “I just thought you should know, you know. Don’t want to make you uncomfortable since I’ve been sleeping in your bed and stuff. Not that I’m– like– planning on doing anything other than sleeping but–”

“Steve,” Eddie rests his palm on Steve’s leg. “I’m not uncomfortable. I’m really glad you told me.”

“Oh,” Steve feels a bit hot, a separate sort of hot from the heat of the room. “You are?”

“Of course!” Eddie leans in, winks in that playful way of his, the warm way that makes Steve feel like he could tell Eddie anything, “I’m really proud of you, sweetheart.”

Steve gulps. “Yeah. Okay. Thanks, Eddie. That, uh, that means a lot.”

Eddie is looking at him with the warmest smile Steve has ever seen. His insides feel ooey and gooey in the best way, like soft marshmallow fluff or a fresh-out-of-the-oven chocolate chip cookie.

One secret down. One to go.

For the first time in his life, Steve seeks someone out after he gets injured.

He comes home with a cut across his arm, after one of the most embarrassing accidents he’s ever had in his career as Spider-Man.

Usually when he gets hit by a car, it’s moving. And he’s usually doing something really cool like swinging across the engine pipe and shooting his web through the open window at whatever perps he’s currently chasing.

Today, he is swinging across New York City, scoping it out. Sometimes, his webs don’t stick properly. Usually this happens in winter, when his artificial web formula doesn’t stick to ice very well. (Steve finds out later that Lucas’ natural webbing sticks to ice just fine, furthering his jealousy for the spiderling.)

He’s swinging over a garbage truck when his web doesn’t catch, and he falls sideways, cutting his arm on the side of the lifting mechanism. He falls onto the icy road, on top of his injured arm, because that’s just his spidey-luck at work. Luckily, it’s a truck parked outside in the middle of the night, so no one seems to see his mistake.

His arm is throbbing by the time he slips through his bedroom window. He peels off his torn suit (his new white spider suit, too, damn it) and replaces it with a white tank and black sweatpants. He walks into the bathroom and grabs his first aid kit, and he’s hit with a feeling he’s never really felt before.

He wants to wake up Eddie. He wants to go get him and ask for comfort. He wants Eddie to tell him to be more careful, and he wants Eddie’s hands on him. His tender, rough hands.

Eddie answers his door with a sleepy frown on his face. “Hey, are you okay?”

Steve turns to his side wordlessly, showcasing his partially-bruised, partially-bleeding bicep. “Can you help me disinfect this?”

Eddie’s eyes widen a fraction of a second before he nods. “Okay, go sit in the bathroom. I’m gonna go get a washcloth.”

Sitting on the edge of the bathtub, Steve inhales the lingering smell of lavender. When Eddie comes in, he carries with him the same smell. “Did you use my French Kiss bubble bar? Wait… Eddie Munson, did you take a bath?”

Eddie’s eyes flit across Steve’s face, probably hoping he won’t yell at him for using his — granted, limited edition — bath bomb. “French kiss?” He asks, voice low.

Maybe he’s trying not to break the silence of the night. Maybe the word kiss has him looking at Steve’s lips, which in return has Steve biting at the skin, his brain screaming at Eddie to fucking do something. “The one shaped like a mountain,” Steve squeaks, partly distracted by the way Eddie’s eyes seem to darken.

Eddie looks up. Blinks. Clears his throat. “Sorry,” he laughs nervously. “It just smelled really good.”

“I’ll have to start getting two of each when I go,” Steve says when Eddie turns to grab the rubbing alcohol. He hisses when the liquid touches the scrape on his arm. He’s been running on shock this entire night, and the first zap of pain washes over the throbbing feeling. The result is a pained whimper, as Eddie lightly presses against his tender bruises. “I – Shit, that smarts – ran into a garbage truck.”

“How the fuck did you manage that, sweetheart?” Eddie questions to distract him, and Steve knows it’s because Eddie is getting peroxide out (Steve is starting to think Eddie doesn’t know much about first aid) but it’s working.

The nickname stuns him into silence, even though Eddie has been using it both frequently and sweetly. Steve likes it. Too much, probably, and he’s so busy thinking about how not to seem like he likes it, that he misses Eddie wrapping some gauze and a bandage around his arm.

“Now you need painkillers and some rest,” Eddie mutters under his breath while he packs up the first aid kit, like he’s talking to himself. When the kit is tucked away, Eddie turns back to Steve and gives him the sweetest smile. “Let’s go to bed, okay?”

Steve follows Eddie to his room, swallows the painkillers dry, and snuggles deep beneath Eddie’s blankets, favoring his injured side. “Do you work tonight?”

The mumble reaches Eddie as he is quite literally crawling over Steve to get back into bed. “Nope. I’ll probably be up in a few hours anyways, though.”

“Oh.”

“Oh?” Eddie faces Steve and gives him a teasing look, “You want me gone?”

“No!” Steve is quick to react, reaching out for Eddie’s sweater in an effort to placate him. His fingers curl into the cable knit. “I meant, oh, like, I don’t want you to get up in a few hours.”

Eddie stares at him, perplexed. His eyes have that same look he gave Steve back when he came home to him baking brownies. It looks like admiration, but it’s something else. Steve can see Eddie’s eyes twinkle even in the dark room. He hates spidey sense sometimes.

“I think the painkillers are kicking in,” Eddie says, like he handed Steve something stronger than two Tylenol pills.

“I just like waking up with you,” Steve continues… and yeah, maybe the painkillers are kicking in. That, or Eddie makes Steve comfortable enough to admit to, frankly, embarrassing thoughts. So Steve does what any adult man would do in his situation, and he pretends to fall asleep.

He can feel Eddie’s eyes on him. And then, ever so soundly, he’s shuffling under the covers, pressing his lips to Steve’s forehead.

Steve really hates his spidey sense.

Although there are less crimes around the holidays, it can be said that the crimes that are committed are often worse in morality and also, unfortunately, fatalities.

Steve has seen a lot of death in his career as Spider-Man. Not at his own hands — he’s made a commitment long ago to keep even his enemies alive; to never kill.

He’s fighting Rhino only one week before Christmas.
